body:
@style95 
Let's try to get proxy approach by getting the test code leverage it.
Can you share the specifics on what have you tried ?

>I am looking for the way to configure proxy in tests code(akka.http.scaladsl.model.HttpRequest).

How you attempted so far to configure the http client?
PG2-1050 passed.   More testing ahead.

To run the code seamlessly in different OS, it will be better for user to run the code without any code changes.
I tried to find the way to use environment variable or configuration rather than change the code.

Please refer to what I tried.

**1. Socks proxy configuration.**
I setup socks proxy with ssh to a container, and configure it in osx system configuration.

 * System Preferences -> Network -> Proxy  -> SOCKS Proxy 
 * `networksetup -setsocksfirewallproxy "Wi-Fi" localhost 8888`

Both the ways did not work.

I could configure the proxy and traffic go through the proxy during web browsing.
But test code traffic didn`t pass through the proxy.

**2. http_proxy environment variable.**

I setup squid http proxy as I mentioned above.
I set environment variable http_proxy and https_proxy

I could send any http request to container using curl.
But test code traffic didn`t pass through the proxy.

**3. gradle http proxy**

I tried to configure proxy in gradle side.

gradle.properties
```
systemProp.http.proxyHost=localhost
systemProp.http.proxyPort=3128
```

* Refercence: https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/build_environment.html#sec:accessing_the_web_via_a_proxy

It did not work.

**4. IntelliJ proxy setup**
I tried to run test code on IntelliJ and configure the proxy in intellij configuration.

Preferences -> Appearance & Behavior -> System Settings -> HTTP Proxy -> Host name: localhost, Port number: 3128

Unfortunately, it did not work also..

At this point, I thought system-wide configuration might not work for the test code.
I started looking into the code itself.

I thought `akka.http.scaladsl.model.HttpRequest` and `AkkaHttpUtils.singleRequest` are the keys.

I look into the following documents.
http://doc.akka.io/docs/akka/2.4.3/scala/http/common/http-model.html
http://doc.akka.io/docs/akka/2.4.7/scala/http/configuration.html#akka-http-core

I found this information, and was trying to find out how to configure proxy in client side as currently Http().outgoingConnection is being used.

```
# IMPORTANT:
    # Please note that this section mirrors `akka.http.client` however is used only for pool-based APIs,
    # such as `Http().superPool` or `Http().singleRequest`.
    client = {
      # The default value of the `User-Agent` header to produce if no
      # explicit `User-Agent`-header was included in a request.
      # If this value is the empty string and no header was included in
      # the request, no `User-Agent` header will be rendered at all.
      user-agent-header = akka-http/${akka.version}
 
      # The time period within which the TCP connecting process must be completed.
      connecting-timeout = 10s
 
      # The time after which an idle connection will be automatically closed.
      # Set to `infinite` to completely disable idle timeouts.
      idle-timeout = 60 s
 
      # The initial size of the buffer to render the request headers in.
      # Can be used for fine-tuning request rendering performance but probably
      # doesn't have to be fiddled with in most applications.
      request-header-size-hint = 512
 
      # The proxy configurations to be used for requests with the specified
      # scheme.
      proxy {
        # Proxy settings for unencrypted HTTP requests
        # Set to 'none' to always connect directly, 'default' to use the system
        # settings as described in http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/technotes/guides/net/proxies.html
        # or specify the proxy host, port and non proxy hosts as demonstrated
        # in the following example:
        # http {
        #   host = myproxy.com
        #   port = 8080
        #   non-proxy-hosts = ["*.direct-access.net"]
        # }
        http = default
 
        # Proxy settings for HTTPS requests (currently unsupported)
        https = default
      }
```

Do you have any idea?
rebased and merged in 47edf410a14b3fdda2a3612fad0ce0b33c30ff79

ðŸ‘Ž To adding exemption. This tests creates so many assets/invokes 100 actions?
If you need to settle the throttle do it outside the suite as we do with other tests.

@rabbah Yep, I think someone mentioned verbally that the we already do that on adjusting the limits for the test suite to allow more requests per minute. 

Can you point to a file line number example so we can follow the same?
Looks in the Jenkins scripts for "settle throttle". But I'm still wondering why you're running into this limit with this suite. Are you running a 100 tests per minute?

>But I'm still wondering why you're running into this limit with this suite. Are you running a 100 tests per minute?

Yes the limit is 60 per minute, so when it gets to 61 requests within the minute it get's the 429 status code
You can also take a look at the ThrottleTests, they settle the limits quite "intelligently".

What's the alternative? An alias to `wsk -i`? That's worse. I have several config files. I switch between them regularly using `WSK_CONFIG_FILE`. So for each I'd make sure they have appropriate settings. It's easier to switch configurations this way then to have one file and change keys etc. in my experience.

Printing a warning will be annoying - you're going to print one per command? No thanks :)

I'm open to alternatives - but the problem is that `wsk -i` is the default otherwise. And there are other tools like `npm wab` and `npm ownen` that needs to know secure vs insecure and having one work around per tool is silly when they use `.wskprops` otherwise.
@csantanapr this is the issue for the pr #1838 - let's have the discussion here instead of the pr?
@markusthoemmes - In the ThrottleTests test suite, the actual throttle limit is not dynamically increased; but that may not be what you are referring to.
There was one detail left in this issue that wasn't implemented/resolved. It is related to this issue: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/1853.
We can update the docs, sure but we should also reconsider this proposal here: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/1144#issue-173616662.
@rabbah, from conversations with @mdeuser, it sounds like all of the API commands in the CLI will need to account for the 202 as well.

> @csantanapr this is the issue for the pr #1838 - let's have the discussion here instead of the pr?

Sure

How is the PR #1838 addressing the problem, and handling concerns with user forgetting if it modifies the ~/.wskprops file to set insecure, and the exposure risk?

I guess I don't have alternatives, I was asking what does the PR #1833 does ?
And that there are no other possible alternatives and just merge the PR and a call it a day.

We currently provide a global `-i` flag for the CLI. We use this flag for all tests and local development because we don't have a trusted certificate installed for local deployment. We can entertain this idea with `letsencrypt` but I'm not sure it's worth the effort (plus they require renewal every 90 days, so more processes).

So that means for local development either every CLI command you enter must have `-i` or you have to create an alias `wsk=wsk -i`.

What the PR does is allow up to configure the CLI and store the setting in `.wskprops`.

Your concern is that one might use the insecure ssl setting with a trusted domain and that's undesirable. But it's no worse that the alias.

This is primarily for local developers and those who have more than one deployment that they work with. I tend to switch between deployments via `WSK_CONFIG_FILE` changes which point to different `.wskprops`. So each would have it's own setting, including insecure ssl (which is off by default).

So what to do about the case where someone sets `-i` in their property file and forgets and now is using the same property file with a trusted domain? Generating a warning on every CLI command is a non-starter. So if we wanted to be cautious about it, one thought is for the CLI to issue a warning when changing `apihost` or `authkey`. I tend to think it's not necessary  - as I said this is for local development - and you have to opt into it.

why not entertain something with less effort and just expose http on port 80  in open for local dev from nginx?

Would look something like
```
wsk property set --apihost http://192.168.33.13
```
The cli will connect over http for dev
Then if user wants to use a secure apihost then setting api host with https
```
wsk property set --apihost https://openwhisk.ng.bluemix.net
```

In this use case no `-i` flag to use, no config file to configure.

This matches what I'm use to, do when dealing with local web servers and doing dev and local testing. I access the web server on `http://localhost:8080` and when access in a secure way when I have my nginx/proxy in front I access using `https://carlos.example.com`

> why not entertain something with less effort and just expose http on port 80 in open for local dev from nginx?

OK good thought - although by extension the tests in the repo should be using `http` vs `-i` (and why do we include self-signed certificates)... but then again this is not fully tested either (although I did add a test to make sure the CLI will allow an `http` api host)... and then why bother allowing `-i` at all?
Thanks for all the good feedback.

> OK good thought - although by extension the tests in the repo should be doing this vs -i but then again this is not fully tested either (although I did add a test to make sure the CLI will allow http).

Agree tests using the cli will need adjusting to not use `-i` anymore, and have tests for the CLI in place that allow for user to configure apihost using protocol `http` or `https` or just domain.

I prefer to see effort invested to this solution than a config file insecure option, if I were given the chance to give my 2 cents.

I think you're asking for a bigger boat - If we add http to the router, then I think all tests will need to run twice: against `http` and `https`. No? (This was the reason we settled on `https`.) Perhaps it's worth revisiting this again.

Note: this could solve some of the problem we have in the catalog where actions that need to use npm openwhisk have to accommodate secure and insecure connections. Going to `http` in addition to `https` would get rid of that ugliness.

I think the tests should not be run twice.
Maybe run all of them with http, and then run one or two tests over https, I think is low risk.

If the tests are to be run let's say in an environment where secure option is available, I would run all tests using https, for example running tests against a staging or production env, or just a VM user setup with proper ssl certificates.

> I think the tests should not be run twice.

Not convinced this flies - how will you know there isn't some protocol hardcoded somewhere and hence will break if you don't test both paths?

We'll have to encode the protocol in ansible for the api host, allow for either deployment, configure the tests accordingly (CLI and REST tests), update all the documentation for each protocol.

Should we reopen https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/428? It seems the issues you're raising are bigger. This issue and corresponding PR was in response to this https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/428#issuecomment-229201967.

Sure re-open #428  it or open a new one.

So back to this issue #1570 and the PR #1838
I have no more to comment.
Adding blocked tagged pending resolution (see #1570 for discussion).

FWIW I use multiple aliases locally to overcome this issue:

```
owsk='WSK_CONFIG_FILE=~/.wskprops-local ~/dev/openwhisk/bin/wsk -i'
pwsk='WSK_CONFIG_FILE=~/.wskprops-prod ~/dev/openwhisk/bin/wsk'
swsk='WSK_CONFIG_FILE=~/.wskprops-stage ~/dev/openwhisk/bin/wsk'
wsk='~/dev/openwhisk/bin/wsk'
```

Just to throw another datapoint in the ring.

A reason not to use different aliases and why it breaks down: if you're working with deployment scripts with others, who use `wsk`, then it breaks. Every app deployment scripts that I've had to work with from others did this, and I've had to change their scripts to use `$WSK` where I can override it from the command line for example. So I've opted for always using `wsk` for convenience and just toggling the `WSK_CONFIG_FILE` through a similar mechanism.

Usually others are working against a production environment (Bluemix) but I'm using a private deployment. Hence the need for a way to change settings.
@csantanapr -   you can decline this PR as I submitted changes to the Kafka package repo instead of here.
I believe the cleanup happened a while ago. Closing as this issue is not actionable as is anymore.
Setting the proxy on the akka-http client should work - it should be possible to do that without the configuration file.

Where is akka-http client being used?
Could I configure application.conf in `common/scala/main/resources`?

> Where is akka-http client being used?

https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tests/src/actionContainers/ActionContainer.scala#L173

>  Could I configure application.conf in common/scala/main/resources?

it's only needed for the tests, right? So I would do that programmatically instead or add the configuration file for the tests only.

EDIT: actually I'm not sure how you predicate the configuration file for `mac` vs `gnu/linux`.
hmm do you have an example?
Argh, the pasted line swallowed the extra space after the date.
Markus showed me the extra space. Two thoughts. Split on regex with space+. Or find out where there's an extra space there at all - there should not be.

@csantanapr, please review.

Local deployment? Likely you didn't deploy the couchdb views if so. You can use `wskadmin db get whisks` to confirm the design doc is installed.

Should this work if couchdb views are not installed??

> How about May be submitted ...

The previous row uses "are allowed".   So I think both rows should use the same convention -- don't care which one as long as its clear.
Yes. List will fail. Everything else will work.
@csantanapr - test suite now implements a more intelligent throttle avoidance.  PG3 268
Travis not responding to build restart, so closing/reopening PR to restart travis

@RSulzmann explained the extra space is from the fixed-space padding.
I suggest we change the split to a regex, eg. ` raw"\s+".r.split(_)...`
@rabbah I think the `contains` check is enough. Nailing the logmessage down so narrowly doesn't really help?
alright - overly paranoid.

@rabbah, every sub-command will have to have the same updates that `action invoke` have here. I'd suggest to merge each updated sub-command individual as it will take some time to update all of them. Also, this PR has a companion.

Generally looks good.  My concerns are around testing.  There is a test on the controller/loadbalancer side for the invoker actors.  Is there a unit test for the health ping through kafka?  Do we still have a composite test to actually go through the motion of an invoker  going down and back?

did you setup couchdb yourself or use the playbooks?

This is very good to have this cleanup now. 

Question I see that now the action can be "protected" meaning any valid subject with a valid keycan invoke. 

How do you envision in the future on how to make the action "private" meaning only the owner subject can invoke it. 
1. It could be by setting an annotation with a "invoke-key" that owner generates a value and set
2. It can be by reusing the anotation require-whisk-auth with another posible value "self", then as long an owkey owned by the owner of the action can invoke

When the view is working correctly, you should be able to list documents this way
` wskadmin db get -v whisks/actions whisks`

My suspicion is that your couchdb is not configured as required (see this issue https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/693 and confirm you've enabled this).

> How do you envision in the future on how to make the action "private" meaning only the owner subject can invoke it.


don't web export it - further the action will get the namespace of the authenticated user and can implement its own ACL.

But I want the benefit of being able to invoke it with http verbs in a private way from the apigateway or other backend, and not to have to incur into the cost of an invocation just to return auth error from inside the action, if I could avoid it by declaring that only the owner is allowed to invoke it then controller can do the auth for me and not waiste work to do the invocation of the action

This is adding authentication - not authorization. It's nearly semantic preserving with removing meta package support for web actions.

I don't dispute adding authorization would be useful - but outside of the scope of this pr, no?
Further you're touching on feature which are related to moving web action enhancements to the core API.

Yes all my comments are outside this PR
This PR as it is is well defined and complete. 

I was just taking opportunity to have a comment about the new annotation require-whisk-auth 

I don't have any further comments. 

Good job ðŸ‘

Can you explain the authentication mechanism which will be provided by this change. I was under the assumption that we can create multiple users under a namespace but when i run the command wskadmin user list #{namespace}, it just displays the current user. For example. i created a user Test1 under Namespace1, so now i change my context using wsk property set --auth {Auth key for Test1}. When i run wsk user list, only the Test1 will be displayed even if i have created Test2 under namespace1. In .wskprops file, namespace will be Namespace1 but when i do wsk namespace list, it will displayTest1 as namespace. 
What is the exact meaning of namespace here and user/auth key ? and the relation between them.

I'm not sure I followed but this does help?

```bash
# create guest 1&2 accounts
$ wskadmin user create guest1 -ns shared
...
$ wskadmin user create guest2 -ns shared
...

# create action in /shared namespace
$ wsk action create /shared/a --docker b -u `wskadmin user get guest1 -ns shared`

# confirm you can access action in /shared namespace
$ wsk action list /shared -u `wskadmin user get guest1 -ns shared`

$ wsk action list /shared -u `wskadmin user get guest2 -ns shared`
/shared/a                                                              private blackbox
```
This is entirely on the API side - generating the join for the binding requires some work in the view with complementary post processing in the controller possibly.
